answers.explanation:
The OCT image is from the left eye. The RNFL becomes thicker nasally as nerve fibers bundle together to form the optic nerve (red box). Therefore, this is an OCT macula OS.

![](/content/media/retina-40-2.webp)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: Is this an OCT image of the right or left eye?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: What abnormal findings are seen on OCT?

answers.answerText: C. Hyper-reflective dots in the vitreous cavity
answers.explanation:
Diffuse hyper-reflective foci are observed in the vitreous space (yellow arrows). The posterior hyaloid is not detached, there is gas between the posterior vitreous and macula/fovea however this is normal in this case.

![](/content/media/retina-40-3.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: On further history, the patient is a type 1 diabetic with poor control of his blood sugar levels. Given this information, what do the hyper-reflective dots in the vitreous likely represent?

answers.explanation: All of the conditions listed above can present as hyper-reflective dots/opacities in the vitreous cavity on OCT. However, given the history of poorly controlled diabetes and the history of vision loss, vitreous hemorrhage is the most likely cause of this patientâ€™s vision loss.

title: Case 40
description: 34M presenting for blurred vision and floaters OS
patientPresentation:
A 34-year-old presents to the emergency department after waking up this morning with blurred vision and floaters OS. On exam, visual acuity is 20/20 OD, 20/60 OS. There is no indirect ophthalmoscope available in the emergency room, but there is surprisingly an OCT machine at your disposal. OCT macula OS is shown below:
